Although the effect is named after Magnus, it was actually known to Isaac Newton who gave a correct explanation for the effect after watching tennis players hit the ball with topspin at his college in Cambridge.  He thought light was made up of classical particles and incorrectly tried to argue in a letter that refraction of light might be due to particles of light undergoing the Magnus effect and bending like you see the ball bend here.

First reason for this effect that I thought of was something like airplane wings. The side of the falling ball spinning upwards accelerates the air current, the othe side slows it down. You see where this goes - faster air is less compressed and ball gets dragged in this direction.

Those ships are really wacky. The only thing Derrick didn’t mention is the pressure drop. The Magnus effect is effectively the same as a wing in terms of the maths. There’s a function (Γ) which determines the strength of the velocity change. In fact, you can define most wings by simply taking a cylinder and deforming it. The flow is deflected, but you also get a pressure difference between upper and lower flows.

The Magnus effect is an observable phenomenon that is commonly associated with a spinning object moving through air or another fluid. The path of the spinning object is deflected in a manner that is not present when the object is not spinning. The deflection can be explained by the difference in pressure of the fluid on opposite sides of the spinning object. The Magnus Effect depends on the speed of rotation.

With the Trac Ball the man throws in a courtyard, the air moving over the ball is moving faster than the air moving under the ball causing lift in a similar way to aerofoils. with the basketball, the same thing is happening. The air in front of the ball is sped up by the friction with the upwards spinning face. on the back of the ball the air is being slowed by the downward spinning face. Fast moving air exerts low pressure while slow moving air exerts high pressure so the ball moves forwards.

I’m surprised he didn’t mention baseball. Not only do pitchers spin every single throw (except knuckleballs) but every batted ball has spin to it (except knuckleballs). Pitching and/or hitting a knuckleball is relatively uncommon but can be awkward to hit or field.

Anyway, I saw the Cardinals take batting practice back in the late ‘90’s. Mark McGwire was a very big guy, used a big bat and had a powerful downswing. He admittedly tried to hit the bottom third of the baseball to create backspin. The batting practice was a sight to behold. While there were a few other players in MLB who could hit the ball nearly as far, no one had the height and soar like McGwire. The ball would hang high in the air, like it was wanting to stay up there, and carry quite far. I am speaking the truth when I say the next ball he hit would be on its way before the first one even landed. So trying to catch them in the stands felt like juggling. It was very entertaining for everyone trying to catch the souvenirs.

Say what you may about him cheating but I’ve never seen anyone hit a baseball like that before, during or after his time. Maybe they should’ve called him Mark McMagnus instead of Big Mac.

Also Bernoulli's principle does apply too. The ball spinning does affect the speed of the layer of air in touch with it, making it that the air gets speeded up (or less slowed down) than in the other side. Bernoulli's principe explains that the energy of air flow depends on speed, preassure (related with temperature aswell) and potential energy in form of graviational potential energy. In the case of the ball the air flow doesn't change altitude nor mass so that gravitational energy remains constant. But as in one side the air moves faster than the other, the faster side has less preassure than the slower side, which creates a force from the high preassure side to the low preassure side. That is what creates the lift force in airfoils that allows planes to fly.

The diagram at 1:18 makes no sense at all because if the air on the right side is not able to resist the ball's spin enough to cause it to spin the other way, then the ball shouldn’t move to the left. The only way the ball should move to the left is 1. if the ball was spinning the other way or 2. if the air on the left travels all the way around the ball parallel with its spin, but that's not what the diagram shows. You see what I mean?
EDIT: Oh wait I get it now, I guess the ball has little resistance against the air so that allows it to easily spin along the air on the right and the left air blowing over it pushes it away from the right air, so that makes sense, yeah. It's just that if the ball's spin was fully resisted by the air, then the diagram would make no sense. And even then, the diagram could still be wrong if the air had enough resistance on the ball's spin to overpower the amount of spin you applied to it and thus not allow it to spin.

Sir actually the explanation you gave i think its a little different from what i learned.

Assuming ball to be spinning clockwise from our point of view ( just for explanation) and it is moving towards right. From ball's frame, air is going to the left.
Now the air passing through the top of ball is relatively slowed down due to frictional forces, and the air passing throught he bottom is speedened up (easily imaginable). Now due to bernouli's principle, faster air exerts less pressure and slower air exerts higher pressure. Hence pressure at the top is higher than that at the bottom so it moves down.
Applying this logic, you get this direction correct as shown in the video.

The video is wrong. Due to Magnus effect, the ball should've moved towards the dam. It's moving away from the dam, therefore its movement is due to other forces than Magnus effect.

Even the explanation animation is wrong. The ball is spinning clockwise, with air going up (or ball is going down, i.e. falling). The right side of the ball moves against the air, while left side moves with the air. Therefore, on the right side air pressure is lower than on the left side.

Thus the ball should move to the right, and while falling from the dam - towards it, not away from it.

I always attributed such actions as simple aerodynamics and nothing more.  Faster moving air has less pressure than slower moving air.  By putting a backspin on the ball, the air speed on the front side of the ball is greater than on the back side of the ball.  This gives greater air pressure on the back side than on the front side, thus effective "thrust" or "lift", much like an airfoil does. Very cool...this is why tennis players usually use lots of topspin - hit it hard with backspin and the ball sails way long and possibly into the back fence. Topspin brings it down into the court AND causes the ball to take a big bounce forward, making it harder to return. You can smash it, and the topspin still brings it down. Also, pro golfers are really good at producing various spins to shape their shots and control the bounces and rolls when the ball lands - such as the hook shot Bubba Watson hit from the trees to win the 2012 Masters. Baseball pitchers use routinely this to fool batters - really any sport with a ball, and you have these interesting effects. Unless you're Tom Brady, in which slight deflation of a football produces the biggest advantage...lol

Well this video is completely wrong.  The ball doesn't move forward because of the Magnus Effect.  The Magnus Effect is an out of date theory proved wrong by NASA in the 1960 with the No Slip Condition Theory & Boundary Layer Theory.  The reason why the ball moves forward is the same reason why planes fly.  The air in front of the ball is moving faster because of the spin causing the pressure in front of the ball to drop.  The air behind the ball slow down due to the spin causing the pressure to increase. This difference in pressure will cause the ball to move forward.  That being said it was the testing of the Magnus Effect and air foils that led to the creation of the No Slip Condition Theory & Boundary Layer Theory and thus has its place in history, but is fundamentally wrong as it ignores basic fluids.

Fluid mechanics you are awesome!! Its all about high and low pressure on each side of the ball..higher velocity of air on one side(implies lower pressure) due to spin and lower velocity on the other(higher pressure) and so resulting net force/pressure on one side..:D

I'll admit, I'm having trouble with the distinction between Magnus and Bernoulli. The sailboat graphic clearly shows air moving faster along the leading edge of the cylinders, slower aft. Low pressure in front, higher pressure aft.

As a kid, I owned a Trac Ball set similar to the jai alai looking racket in your video. It came with heavy plastic balls, as well as much lighter balls made of Styrofoam. If the lighter ball was launched with enough back-spin, the ball would actually loop-the-loop. Inspired by this, I began experimenting with cylinders from ink pens. Finding a smooth, round cylinder with no taper, and about three inches long, the cylinder could be launched by placing it between two heavy books near the far end. While applying pressure to the top book, and sliding it slowly back, the cylinder could be spit out the forward end with enough back-spin to cause it to loop-the-loop as well. It was amazing to see because there was almost no forward momentum. It seemed to hover. That must have been the Magnus effect. I was astonished because the lift created was counterintuitive. The leading edge of the cylinder was rotating up, and yet the cylinder rose against it.

The biggest misconception about the Magnus Effect is that it is just a consequence of Bernoulli's principle. It's not. This can be demonstrated by varying the surface roughness of the ball. Smooth balls can actually curve in the opposite direction due to the 'reverse Magnus effect' because flow over one side is laminar while the other is turbulent. This is a great reference on the shortcomings of Bernoulli's principle explanations: http://math.mit.edu/~bush/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Beautiful-Game-2013.pdf

@Veritasium  So we studied this in aerodynamics in college where we studied flow effects form a first principles.  I'm a bit rusty since I don't work on aircraft professionally anymore, but as I recall, it wasn't so much of an effect of the ball's spin "dragging" the air around it, but rather more that the ball's spin caused the flow to speed up on once side, and slow down on the other (from skin friction drag or something similar).  We were able to derive it in class for inviscid fluids (reasonable approximation in the case shown in the video) based on bernoulli's principle. It all boils down to differential pressures.  From what I can remember, this was the point where we started using a mathematical "vortex" to predict flow effects around arbitrary wing shapes.  It all worked out really nicely on paper, and it's really awesome to see it so distinctly in something as simple as a basketball.

The statement at 1:15, being "The ball pushes air one way, so the air applies an equal force on the ball the other way" describes third-law pairs, which alone do not result in any net force. This description is wrong, or at least incomplete. The air on the left, being shear-dragged by the surface of the ball, is moving faster, creating a low pressure zone while the air on the right side is slower, creating a higher pressure zone. The unequal pressures on either side of the ball result in the net force which pushed the ball.

Here's a MATLAB program for simulating the Magnus Effect
---------------------------------

% Parameters
rho=1.2;           % Density of air (kg/m^3)
mass=4.5e-2;       % Mass of ball (kg)
radius=4.5e-2;     % Ball radius (m) 
g=9.8;             % Acceleration due to gravity (m/s^2)
LS=1.0;            % Length scale for non-dimensionalisation
TS=sqrt(LS/g);     % Time scale for non-dimensionalisation

% Prompt user for initial speed, angle, and backspin
speed_dim=input('Enter initial speed in m/s: ');
angle=input('Enter initial angle in degrees: ');
omega_dim=input('Enter backspin in rad/s: ');

% Convert to radians and non-dimensionalise initial speed and omega
angle=angle*pi/180;
speed=TS*speed_dim/LS;
omega=TS*omega_dim; 

% Initial value of lift coefficient times speed
force_ratio=0.5*pi*rho*omega*radius^3*speed/mass;
disp(['Initial lift to gravity ratio: ',num2str(force_ratio)]);

% Initial position and velocity
pos=[0 0]; 
vel=speed*[cos(angle) sin(angle)];

% Non-dimensional timestep
tau=0.001;  % Time step

% Midpoint method integration
n=0;
while pos(2)>=0

  % Store position for plotting
  n=n+1;
  x(n)=pos(1); y(n)=pos(2);
  time(n)=(n-1)*tau;

  % New acceleration term
  lift_coeff=0.5*pi*rho*omega*radius^3/mass; 
  acc_lift=lift_coeff*[-vel(2),vel(1)];

  % Net acceleration
  acc=acc_lift-[0 1];
 
  % Midpoint method
  pos=pos+tau*vel+0.5*tau^2*acc;
  vel=vel+acc*tau;

end

% Plot the trajectory
figure(1);

So I have one I was wondering if you'd like to puzzle through. 

In airsoft guns (a system much like paintball but shooting 6mm solid core balls instead) backspin is applied to the BBs to provide a longer flatter trajectory. (the magnus effect, obviously) The point of curiosity though is in the barrel. You see the backspin is applied at the very beginning of the barrel, the chamber end. There has been much speculation about what the BB actually does going down the barrel prior to its exit. 

What actually does happen? Well, surprisingly, experiments show the BB rides on the ceiling. Nobody has explained why this is though, and the results have become so controversial quite a number of physicists who've seen it have flat out denied the results of the experiments. 

So the question is why does this behavior occur?

edit
I feel I should make this a little bit more clear: the BB is driven down the barrel by air pressure from behind, and is not a gas-seal with the barrel. Because of this, while in the barrel, the BB could be seen as traveling in the opposite direction relative to the air in certain respects; the BB should hypothetically display "topspin" and the magnus effect would drive it downward toward the floor rather than ceiling. This is why our observations that it does not is so surprising.

The experimental methodology used to determine the BB's behavior in the barrel was to coat the bore evenly with scribing fluid, fire a few hundred rounds through it, and then either scope the bore or cut it open. The wear patterns in the scribing fluid show the BB's location. Furthermore, particularly in soft brass barrels, longitudinal scratches in the bore can be observed from where the BB contacts. These are also found on the BB ceiling. They are also fairly long and even, suggesting that the BB truly is riding on the ceiling, rather than oscillating rapidly "bouncing" or anything like that.
